cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:4

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The two basic elements that have brought information under the protection of the law are the confidential nature of the information and the business value of the information to the owner as a result of such confidentiality. Where these two elements can be established, information will generally be protected from disclosure or misuse.
The courts have considered a number of factors[1] when evaluating whether certain information should be classed as “confidential”, including the extent to which the information:
is generally known or unknown to others;[2]
is known to others within the specific industry or trade, i.e., outside the actual business entity;
is known to others within or connected to the business entity;
is capable of acquisition elsewhere by those outside the business entity;
is the subject of measures to ensure that the relative secrecy of the information remains intact; and
in some minimum or basic way is unique, original or novel.[3]

Each of these factors is important to the determination. Of course, often it is a combination of factors that supports a court's findings. See for example, Alberta Productions Corp. v. Canada Lands Co. CLC, where the court noted that the relevant idea had: received broad circulation, been discussed openly, was the product of a number of contributors, was being utilized by others and was part of the public domain.[4] However, after outlining a list of factors to be considered in determining whether information has the inherent quality of uniqueness, the court emphasized:
These factors are useful, but as Fullager J., states in Deta Norminees, [1979] V.R. 167, at p. 193, they are not exhaustive:

I apprehend that neither he [namely Gowans, J., in Ansell's case] nor McInerney, J., in Mense v. Milenkovic, [1973] V.R. at 796-798, intended to convey that one should slavishly check off the factors against the information, as if one were counting spots on some strange creature to see if it was indeed the species of leopard illustrated in the picture book.[5]
The following sections will elaborate on how the court decisions to date have dealt with these factors.

The actual wording used has been almost as varied as the case law. See Techform Products Ltd. v. Wolda (2000), 1 C.C.E.L. (3d) 118, 5 B.L.R. (3d) 111, 5 C.P.R. (4th) 25 (Ont. S.C.J.), supp. reasons 5 C.P.R. (4th) 289 (Ont. S.C.J.). However, note the reversal of this decision by the Ontario Court of Appeal at (2001), 206 D.L.R. (4th) 171, 56 O.R. (3d) 1, 150 O.A.C. 163 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 213 D.L.R. (4th) vi.

Dynamex Canada Franchise Holdings Inc. v. P&D Investments Ltd. (2009), 177 A.C.W.S. (3d) 794 (Ont. S.C.J.); Aram Systems Ltd. v. NovAtel Inc., [2009] 3 W.W.R. 725 (Alta. Q.B.), affd 8 Alta. L.R. (5th) 199 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 78 C.P.R. (4th) vi.

Not novel in the sense required by patent law: see Promotivate International Inc. v. Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd. (1985), 23 D.L.R. (4th) 196, 53 O.R. (2d) 9 (H.C.J.); Talbot v. General Television Corp. Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.); Kewanee Oil Co. v. Bicron Corp., 416 U.S. 470, 476 (1974); Enterprise Excellence Corp. v. Royal Bank of Canada (2002), 20 C.P.R. (4th) 34 (Ont. S.C.J.). By way of comparison to this list of factors, see those set forth in the Restatement of the Law of Torts (1939), § 759. See also the American case of Forest Laboratories Inc. v. Formulations Inc., 299 F. Supp. 202, 205 (E.D. Wisc. 1967), wherein the court set forth six propositions to be considered when determining whether something is “secret”: (1) the extent to which the information is known outside the business; (2) the extent to which it is known by employees and others involved in the business; (3) the extent of the measures taken to guard the secrecy of the information; (4) the value of the information to the business and to competitors; (5) the amount of effort or money expended in developing the information; and (6) the ease or difficulty with which the information could be properly acquired or duplicated by others.
Alberta Productions Corp. v. Canada Lands Co. CLC, [2001] A.J. No. 1151 at para. 193.
